With more to come.Karl Urban in TIFFs Midnight Madness opener Dredd 3D.  (ALLIANCE FILMS)  Thu. Aug. 30 2012Wondering what to see at this months Toronto International Film Festival? Here is a selection of capsule reviews by Star movie critic Peter Howell movie writer Linda Barnard and entertainment writers Bruce DeMara Raju Mudhar and Tony Wong. Titles of recommended movies are preceded by a . Find screening times and other festival information at tiff.net/thefestival.90 Minutes Norways Eva Sorhaug crafts a drama that is deceptively banal in the early going introducing a trio of everyday domestic situations and then she pulls her camera back and were suddenly in different hellish scenarios. Straddling horror and social commentary all are linked to the exploration of the final 90 minutes of life. This challenging film isnt easy viewing but its brave filmmaking that explores violence in society a topic that resonates given the recent sentencing of Norwegian mass murderer Anders Brevik. Linda BarnardAfter the Battle A soapy story dulls Yousry Nasrallahs Egyptian timely drama of the aftermath of the Arab Spring social uprisings which nevertheless asks the pointed question Whats more important jobs or democracy? Based on "The Battle of the Camels" of early 2011 in which camel and horse riders clashed with government forces in Tahrir Square it follows the travails of humble horseman Mahmoud (Bassem Samra) who gets caught in life-changing events both in the street and at home (female trouble times two). All politics may be personal but this just gets simplistic and sudsy. Peter HowellAmour Michael Hanekes dramatic two-hander the Palme dOr winner at Cannes 2012 is a quietly devastating illustration of how tough the "for better or worse" marriage pact can be when "or worse" occurs. An elderly couple (veteran French actors Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva) are put to the test when the wife suffers one stroke and then another robbing her first of speech and then mobility. Together they must find a way to endure as the end approaches. Its one of the simplest and arguably the most passionate films of Hanekes incredible career sure to be a candidate for Best Foreign-Language Film at the next Academy Awards. PHAnna Karenina Joe Wrights high-concept retelling of Tolstoys famous morality tale about love seduction and duty (aided with a pared-down script by Oscar-winner Tom Stoppard) wont be everybodys cup of borscht. But it is so gorgeous and stylistically wrought its hard to take your eyes off the elaborate spectacle. Wrights version takes place in a lavish 19th-century theatre much of it onstage. The carefully choreographed set pieces and stunning costumes highlight Keira Knightleys measured portrayal of the alternating flighty and tragic heroine with Jude Law as her reserved cuckolded husband Alexei and Aaron Johnson as the dashing Count Vronsky who steals her heart and destroys her soul. LBArticle Continued BelowAntiviral Obviously influenced by his dad Davids early work but also showing a strong personal style Brandon Cronenbergs feature debut is a dark satire with a point -- a needle point. It presents a dire future world where celebrity worship has degraded to the degree where the illnesses and cloned flesh of the famous are sold to obsessed admirers who are eager to share the pain. Caleb Landry Jones (X-Men First Class) is a disease hustler whose schemes hit fever pitch; Sarah Gadon (Cosmopolis) is his infected infatuation. Its visceral but it definitely grows on you. PHArgo Ben Affleck skillfully manipulates the tension in edge-of-your-seat thriller Argo a story thats familiar to Canadians but is anything but predictable. The Canadian Caper where six Americans sought refuge at Canadian Ambassador Ken Taylors Tehran residence following bloody student uprisings gets a dramatic new chapter when CIA exfiltration specialist Tony Mendez (Affleck) comes up with a radical idea to get then out of the country by helping them pose as a Canadian film crew on a location scout. Alan Arkin almost steals the picture as Hollywood producer Lester Siegel shades of Dustin Hoffman in Wag the Dog. LBAt Any Price Iowas farmlands form an unlikely backdrop for this tale of father-son conflict set in the high-stakes world of modern agri-business. Dennis Quaid shines as the Great Santini of the seed corn sales world a farmer spouting advice likely gleaned from motivational posters to his son Dean (Zac Efron) who sees his future on the NASCAR track not in the field. The in-car track scenes are intense; so is Quaids performance as a desperate man who sees ethics and morality in shades of grey. Newcomer Maika Monroe is impressive as Deans girlfriend and Efron does well as a sullen kid whose dreams die hard but this is Quaids picture. LBBerberian Sound Studio Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain. But do look closely at the timid little English guy in the Italian sound studio who is slowly unraveling like an old reel-to-reel tape. Mamas boy Gilderoy (Toby Jones) is out of his comfort zone (and possibly his mind) working audio for a schlocky Italian horror film which the bullying director and producer have made an ordeal on both sides of the microphone. Writer/director Peter Strickland hat-tips David Lynchs Mulholland Drive for this descent-into-madness psychodrama but its smartly done. Bonus is the demonstration of old-school foley effects -- who knew a radish could terrify? PHBestiaire Canadian auteur Denis Cote normally confines his astringent gaze to the odd workings of the human animal. Here he shares the frame with beasts of fur and horn at a Quebec safari park where stares of curiosity and indifference flash between both sides of the cage. And look closely at how Cote approaches those metal bars -- youre never quite sure what will pop into view and who the real prisoners are. Equally inspired by a medieval picture book and by our chronic disrespect for the natural world Cotes quietly awesome film insists its our minds that are really locked up. PHBeyond the Hills God and the devil work in mysterious ways for beset nuns in a remote Moldavian monastery as two close friends fall on opposite sides of strict ideology. Romanias Cristian Mungiu masterly directs this heartbreaking tug of faith vs. free will which deservedly won a shared Best Actress award for female leads Cosmina Stratan and Cristina Flutur at the Cannes Film Festival in May. PHBurn It Up Djassa The music is hot and the steel is cold in this ghetto tragedy a searing debut by Ivory Coast director Lonesome Solo. Rebel youth Tony (Abdoul Karim Konate) carries both a tune and a chip on his shoulder as he swaggers through his Abidjan neighbourhood of Wassakara. He watches his reckless young sister (Adelaide Ouattara) and maintains cool relations with his cop brother (Mamadou Diomande) but then the tough words of a gangbanger narrator start to sound more like prophecy than braggadocio. PHDetroit Unleaded Lebanese-American filmmaker Rola Nashef makes an entertaining debut with Detroit Unleaded an Arab-American culture-clash comedy with a distinct Clerks vibe set in a family-owned gas station in a rundown Detroit hood. Sami (E.J. Assi) who works in the bulletproof cage installed after his dad was gunned down while running the gas-mart has bigger dreams than his co-owner cousins limited ambitions. Chief among them is getting together with spirited beauty Naj (Nada Shouhayib). But there are strict rules of behaviour among these guys and gals that hardly favour women even if it is America cuz. LBDredd 3D This film adaptation of the beloved British comic wipes the slate clean from the stink of the 1995 version starring Sylvester Stallone. Set in a post-apocalyptic future in which 800 million people live in Mega City One Dredd (Karl Urban) has to take a rookie judge (Olivia Thirlby) with psychic powers out to investigate a homicide in a 200-storey slum. The only flaw is that some of the effects combined with 3D wind up looking cartoony and unintentionally hilarious. Essentially a futuristic take on Die Hard or The Raid Redemption this is a violent gory and faithful execution of the character that fans should rejoice at. Raju MudharThe End of Time Peter Mettlers poetic lens has inquired into everything from personal fulfillment (Gambling Gods and LSD) to the Northern Lights (Picture of Light). Now hes after his most elusive prey yet the very human concept of time. Following a global path that leads him from a pro-astronaut to proton smashers and from a Hawaiian lava watcher to Henry Fords defunct Detroit assembly line the Toronto cinematographer/director makes a profound statement on what makes all of us tick. Its of a piece with Patricio Guzmans Nostalgia for the Light a film that similarly finds miraculous unity in seemingly random things. PHFoxfire Confessions of a Girl Gang Cannes Palme dOr winner Laurent Cantet (The Class) wrote the screenplay and directs this compelling drama that sticks closely to Joyce Carol Oates novel about a girl gang in 1950s upstate New York (filmed in Sault Ste. Marie Ont.) and their charismatic revolutionary-minded leader Margaret "Legs" Sadovsky. Impressive performances from Canadian actresses -- mostly newcomers -- as the teens from the wrong side of the tracks who fight back when wronged by local males. Far superior to the 1996 film version that starred a then-unknown Angelina Jolie as Legs. LBFree Angela amp; All Political Prisoners A new generation meets a legendary activist and educator in Shola Lynchs sympathetic and powerful portrait of Angela Davis a stunning orator who struck fear into the heart of the white establishment in the turbulent late 1960s. Fired from her UCLA teaching post for being a member of the Communist Party Davis bought guns in the wake of death threats. What followed made her an international lightning rod for racial equality and human rights whose image -- a willowy woman with a massive afro -- became a pop culture fixture. Not all questions are answered by Davis now 68 and others interviewed which makes the doc less impactful that it could have been. LBHotel Transylvania Every movie monster ever imagined seems to have been included in this tale from Sony Pictures Animation. That means adults as well as older kids -- say 12 and up -- can share the fun in this wacky fast-paced story about a vampire (voiced by Adam Sandler) who presides over a hotel resort for monsters with zombie bellhops and witches with broomsticks as maids as he tries to protect his daughter from the dangerous world outside -- dangerous to monsters at least. The 3D effects are dizzying at times but marvelous and the wit and zaniness is maintained throughout. Bruce DeMara.The Hunt Mads Mikkelsen deservedly won the Best Actor award at Cannes for his role as a 40-year-old kindergarten teacher whose life is all but destroyed after a young girl falsely accuses him of sexual impropriety. Before the quiet teacher has a chance to defend himself he is attacked and ostracized by rush-to-judgment vigilantes his best friend among them. Denmarks Thomas Vinterberg (The Celebration) directs with confidence engaging the mind and tweaking the conscience. PHHyde Park on Hudson Bill Murray makes a charming Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Laura Linney a stoic mistress Daisy but theyve both got their work cut out for them with the wafer-thin screenplay which Richard Nelson adapted from his BBC radio play of the same name. Titled for FDRs upstate New York retreat where Americas longest-serving president took refuge -- and rumoured sexual liaisons -- as World War II threatened Roger Michells film struggles for definition as either daffy comedy or insiders view of history. Samuel West and Olivia Colman steal scenes as visiting King George VI and wife Queen Elizabeth (the future Queen Mum) befuddled by hot dogs and emboldened by booze but The Kings Speech 2 this isnt. PHIn Another Country Beach puzzler plays to fans of Hong Sang-soos frolics but wont expand the South Korean masters reach even with a very game Isabelle Huppert adding some marquee appeal. She plays three different women each named Anne in three stories that pivot around the same hotel in the seaside resort town of Mohang. Each Anne is a figment of an imaginative film student seeking anxiety relief. The title tips to this as a funhouse mirror image of Hongs earlier Night and Day in which Koreans visiting Paris grapple with French culture. PHInescapable Canadian writer/director Rubba Nadda reteams with Cairo Time star Alexander Siddig for a timely but uneven political thriller set just as the Arab Spring is poised to set Syria aflame. A former intelligence agent Adib (Siddig) is forced to return to his homeland to rescue his daughter Muna who has gone to Damascus to learn more about her fathers mysterious past. In a country with no less than 15 different spy agencies Adib must turn to old contacts as he navigates his way through a deadly maze of intrigue and deceit. Nadda nails some of the paranoia and claustrophobia of living in a police state though the end result is not entirely satisfying. BDIn the Fog A better title might be Ivan for All Seasons a WWII Russian railway workers claimed nyet to Nazi finkdom is disbelieved by his comrades in a German-occupied Belorussian village. An opening hanging shows the cost of resisting and also the fury of villagers seeking a scapegoat. As accused worker Sushenya (Vladimir Svirski) is marched to certain doom flashbacks reveal how truth is the real fog of this war. Insightful dialogue and acting partially redeem a glacial pace in this second feature by My Joys Sergei Loznitsa. PHKrivina Haunted and homesick Bosnian immigrant Miro (Goran Slavkovic) finds life in Toronto trying. Rootless by nature and circumstance he returns to his homeland after receiving word that his old friend Dado not seen for 20 years has been accused of war crimes. But which man is he really seeking? Torontos Igor Drljaca turns detective work into surreal poetry in his absorbing feature debut leaving us to fill in the gaps as he follows a winding path Joseph Conrad and Raymond Chandler might recognize. The camera hovers expectantly; the sound hints of menace. PHA Late Quartet As an acclaimed international string quartet gets ready to celebrate its 25th anniversary an announcement by its most senior member throws the company into a crisis that threatens to tear the company apart. Director/co-writer Yaron Zilberman has assembled a master class of great actors including Christopher Walken Philip Seymour Hoffman Catherine Keener and Mark Ivanir to spin a story that may seem too highbrow for some tastes but is in fact pleasingly filled with down-to-earth passion. BDLaurence Anyways The third feature by Quebecs Xavier Dolan (Jai tue ma mere) isnt an outright failure but neither is it an unqualified success. Its a gender-identity love story between a man named Laurence (Melvil Poupaud) who believes hes really female and a woman named Fred (Suzanne Clement) who isnt quite sure whether her heart beats according to gender or to desire. Poupaud and Clement render love and confusion with equal empathy but Dolan indulges himself with a flabby screenplay. The story just doesnt have the heft that its 161-minute running time implies. PHLeviathan Ever been to sea Billy? Youll feel right in the deep watching this astonishing piece of pure cinema which forsakes narrative for its you-are-there trawl through the conjoined lives of fishermen and their various catches in the waters of New Bedford Mass. Its the legendary place where Herman Melville situated Moby Dick and every twitch of a tattooed muscle flick of a fin crash of a wave and squawk of seagull is nabbed by a battery of cameras with the footage edited for maximum immersion. Emphatically not for three-act moviegoers or the easily seasick. But the adventurous will be hooked by what co-directors Lucien Castaing-Taylor (Sweetgrass) and Verena Paravel have wrought. PHLike Someone in Love More droll than profound Abbas Kiarostamis first Japanese sojourn tolls missed connections and lost chances in a muddled narrative that skirts fantasy and reality. An elderly professor (Tadashi Okuno) falls for a Tokyo call girl (Rin Takanashi) who is leading a double life a student by day she walks the streets by night. Kiarostami seems under some kind of spell too. Entranced by the glamour of a new city the Iranian master stays on the surface failing to find meaning in ambiguity as he did so well with Certified Copy a 2010 film that still resonates. PHLooper A sci-fi film may seem odd for this years TIFF gala opener but its not your usual raygun routine. Skillfully bending genres since he first smashed with Brick in 2005 Rian Johnson puts that films star Joseph Gordon-Levitt into an identity-crisis thriller set in the Kansas of 2044. JGL plays Joe a "looper" (hit man) working for innovative mobsters of the year 2074 who use a time machine to send their victims back three decades for untraceable bullets and burning. Fast cash is just a shot away for ice-cool Joe and his blunderbuss -- until a new crime kingpin decides to "close the loop" and the mirror threatens. Bruce Willis and Emily Blunt co-star in this future shocker with smarts. PHLove is All You Need Denmarks Oscar-winning Susanne Bier (In a Better World) turns Woody Allen for this Italy-set romantic comedy of love after rejection even using (and overusing) Dean Martins "Thats Amore" for its cheesy soundtrack. But theres some real grit mixed with the treacle and strong lead performances by Piers Brosnan as a workaholic and grumpy businessman and Trine Dyrholm as the hairdresser who may just tame this lions mane. A big bonus is the gorgeous photography of its sun-drenched Sorrento locale. PHMekong Hotel Waters are rising and so are strange spirits in the latest by Thailands multimedia artist Apichatpong Weerasethakul who won the 2010 Palme dOr at Cannes for his poetic ghost story Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives. More a collection of ideas than a fully realized concept essentially visual notes for an older unproduced project called Ecstasy Garden the one-hour film packs young romantics obscure ghosts and a maternal vampire in a hotel overlooking the Mekong River in northeast Thailand. Gorgeous acoustic guitar brings everything together imparting a mood of melancholy under Apichatpongs serene gaze. PHOn the Road Yasss yasss . . . Director Walter Salles (The Motorcycle Diaries) really gets Sal Dean Marylou amp; Kerouac amp; all the madness amp; sadness amp; angels along the road to enlightenment as Jack Kerouacs 1957 Beat Generation novel finally hits the big screen. Long feared unfilmable due to its fragmented narrative and jazz-influenced dialogue it comes together very nicely under the completely engaged direction of Salles. He guides an eager cast that includes Twilight star Kristen Stewart plus Sam Riley Garrett Hedlund Kirsten Dunst and Viggo Mortensen. PHNo Gael Garcia Bernal plays a Chilean version of Mad Mens advertising ace Don Draper called upon to sell the "no" side of a national plebiscite that will confirm or topple the dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet -- and the fix for "si" is likely already in. Based on real events of 1988 Pablo Larrains tightly framed film is a mesmerizing realistic and often hilarious look at the cynical politics of power and the magic required to sell a negative as a positive. Say yes to No. PHThe Paperboy A urinating Nicole Kidman shirtless Zac Efron relentless ShakyCam and a croc-bitten script add up to bad news in this campy and swampy melodrama by Lee Daniels (Precious). Set in a racially charged and kinky Florida of the 1960s and narrated by Macy Gray it has Matthew McConaughey as a newshound chasing a scoop about John Cusacks death-row inmate with eyebrow-raising interruptions from a hot-to-trot Kidman and a bedazzled Efron. Theres a lot of heavy breathing on the screen but youll be the one seeking the cold shower afterwards. PHParadise Love Ulrich Seidls depressing sex-tourism satire plays as cautionary tale for libidinous travellers. It follows the sexcapades of Teresa (Margarethe Tiesel) a lonely 50-year-old Austrian who treks to Kenya seeking easy bedspring action. She has no idea what shes getting into. By turns amusing frightening and anything but erotic the film should be mandatory viewing for anyone who thinks sex tourism is a romp. But it leaves you hoping Seidl forgets about plans to make this part of a trilogy. PHThe Perks of Being a Wallflower Sure to resonate with the generation that grew up with and revered his 1999 young adult novel writer Stephen Chbosky who also directs has made a film version that is clearly dedicated to them. Charlie (Logan Lerman) a shy freshman newly emerged from a painful depression tries to fit in at high school and does so with the help of Sam (Emma Watson in her first big post-Harry Potter role) and her stepbrother Patrick (Ezra Miller). Its no John Hughes reinvention; these kids are more self-absorbed than insightful. LBPost Tenebras Lux A devil carrying a toolbox a man ripping off his own head and a nude orgy are just some of the cascading images in Carlos Reygadass latest and most personal film which won the directing prize at Cannes despite baffling many who saw it. The title roughly translates as "After Darkness Light" hinting at spiritual redemption. Whether it all adds up to anything meaningful or if Reygadas even intends it to have any literal meaning may be all in the eye of beholders -- who will be held in thrall regardless. PHOut in the Dark Israeli-born director Michael Mayer co-wrote his first feature-length film about two gay men -- one Israeli one Palestinian -- whose love for each other meets all kinds of obstacles including the division caused by long-standing political issues and conservative family values. Nicholas Jacob as Nimr and Michael Aloni as Roy demonstrate great screen chemistry as the star-crossed lovers in a film that challenges the Arabic proverb love finds its way. BDPicture Day TIFF 2012 Rising Star Tatiana Maslany stars in made-in-Toronto Picture Day as Claire a rebellious teen who appears outwardly annoyed to be repeating her final year of high school but secretly finds it an ideal place to hide out from the adult world. Maslany is terrific as the world-weary smart-talking teen who falls for older musician Jim (Steve McCarthy) while best bud Henry (Spencer Van Wyck) the kid she once babysat pines for her. First-time feature writer-director Kate Melville shows promise working with a bare-bones production budget that adds a pleasing roughness to the film. LBQuelques Heures de Printemps Gravel-voiced French actor Vincent Lindon plays recent prison parolee Alain a 48-year-old single former truck driver whose error in judgment forces him to move back home with his mother wonderfully underplayed by Helene Vincent. Theres clearly history between these two but will his mothers cancer diagnosis and her decision to take some drastic action as a result change their stormy relationship? A methodical film director Stephane Brize saves the best for last delivering a finale with an emotional jolt. LBReality Matteo Garrone won the second-place Grand Prix at Cannes 2008 for his Mafia drama Gomorrah and he nabbed the honour again this year for this darkly satirical dive into the emotional swamp of reality TV. When humble Naples fishmonger Luciano (Aniello Arena) is invited to audition to be one of the contestants on the Italian version of Big Brother his first reaction is to scoff. Hes one of the most level-headed people in his neighbourhood and he has a wife (Loredana Simioli) and three children to support. But when it suddenly seems that Luciano might actually land a Big Brother spot ego and ambition cloud his mind. Reality understands how fame can corrupt even those who arent famous. PHRebelle (War Witch) The ghosts of murdered villagers that haunt a young girl brutally forced to become a child soldier in Montreal writer-director Kim Nguyens much-lauded Rebelle mirror the films effect on an audience. Much of it is down to Congolese native and screen newcomer Rachel Mwanza whose award-winning natural performance as Komona made to join a ragtag rebel force in an unnamed African country at age 12 amid unspeakable cruelty is riveting. LBThe Road North His wife has left him and Helsinki concert pianist Timo (Samuli Edelmann) is doing his best to hold up the cliche about dour Finns in Mika Kaurismakis charming father-and-son road trip comedy. But his absentee dad fat wheezy chainsmoking Leo (a wonderfully dry comic turn by Vesa-Matti Loiri) shows up on his doorstep after 30 years and has other ideas about life and love. Leo who isnt too good with playing by the rules wants Timo to drive him to northern Finland where he some startling answers await about why he walked out on his family. LBRoom 237 That room number opens the door to the darkest corner of Stanley Kubrick worship wherein rabid fans of the late directors The Shining congregate online to speculate about supposedly hidden messages in the film. Director Rodney Ascher discovers several strands of conspiracy theories including a faked Apollo 11 moon landing and Nazi Holocaust and Native American genocide allegories. The common thread is that Kubrick must have been making more than just a simple adaptation of Stephen Kings spooky hotel story when he filmed his 1980 chiller. The really creepy thing is that some of these loons actually make sense. PHA Royal Affair This Lavish Danish costume drama offers fresh perspective on the true story of King Christian VII and the country doctor who ended up running Denmark in his stead. Childish and mad -- played with awards-worthy depth by Mikkel Folsgaard -- the king is hardly a welcome sight for his justifiably unhappy wife Caroline (Alicia Vikander) who narrates the story. Mads Mikkelsen is compelling as German country doctor Johann Friedrich Struensee who arrives bearing ideas from the Enlightenment. He gains the kings trust and eventually considerable political power. With his eye on social reform not personal gain hes also smitten with Caroline. Lovely to look at and filled with intrigue its a satisfying period piece. LBRust and Bone Best Actress Oscar winner Marion Cotillard makes a strong bid for a repeat win with her uncompromising performance as an amputee seeking and resisting love in this French melodrama by Jacques Audiard (A Prophet). Cotillard bravely eschews both makeup and modesty in the role of Stephanie a trainer of killer whales who is drawn into an unlikely and uncertain romance with a hard-nosed street brawler (Matthias Schoenaerts) after a workplace tragedy radically alters her body and her life. PHThe Secret Disco Revolution Toronto documentarian Jamie Kastner takes a satirical approach to the rise and fall of disco using a trio of Spandex and polyester-clad groovesters to explore his mock-scholarly theory that an underground manifesto furthering sexual racial and gay liberation gave rise to the four-four beat revolution. Its all an excuse to compile impressive dance-floor footage of the oogie-boogie era along with interviews with former disco royalty like The Village People and Gloria Gaynor. Theres even some egghead input as University of Southern California professor Alice Echols explains Donna Summers "Love to Love You Baby" is actually "the feminist critique of three-minute sex." LBThe Sessions A gentle often very funny and unblinkingly honest look at physical intimacy and the disabled The Sessions stars John Hawkes (Winters Bone) as writer Mark OBrien who spends his life in an iron lung but yearns for human touch -- of the erotic kind. Enter Helen Hunt as the sex surrogate who helps fulfill his wish to lose his virginity. William H. Macy co-stars as a sympathetic priest. This Sundance crowd pleaser was a double winner at the fest with good reason. LBSmashed A superb career-making performance by Mary Elizabeth Winstead as Kate a young married Grade 1 teacher who is what they call a "high-functioning alcoholic." Her husband (Aaron Paul) is her drinking buddy but the party is getting increasingly out of hand as evidenced in the first shocking scenes. The script goes to some predictable places but is lifted by the supporting cast especially Megan Mullally as her trusting principal and Mary Kay Place as Kates similarly afflicted mother. LBStories We Tell Actor/filmmaker Sarah Polleys personal documentary is extraordinary in every way from its post-modern structure to the raw emotion of its carefully revealed family secrets. Dont go by the TIFF program book which discreetly holds back crucial info the film isnt just about any family but Polleys own. She and her loved ones summon the necessary courage not only to delve into extremely difficult subjects but also to face up to life-altering consequences. Its a film of truth memory and reconciliation with no clear path. You just have to trust in Polleys steely determination and follow her relentless lens. In a word WOW. PHTabu Is Tabu about the relationship of a woman with her housekeeper or is it about the legacy of Portuguese colonialism and the emotional burden of an oppressive past? At the end of Portuguese director Miguel Gomess black and white melodrama it doesnt really matter because the reward is a stunning photographic narrative -- a love story told as sweeping parable. But to get there takes an investment by the viewer. Still Tabu is accessible because it never strays from the idea that it is about the most base of human emotions -- even if told with an unconventional sensibility. Tony WongTower Underachieving Torontonian Derek (Derek Bogart vivid) still has his wisdom teeth at age 34 but they dont attest to much wisdom. He has yet to launch from the parental home works without zeal at his uncles construction firm and fidgets with a cartoon a girl and a pesky raccoon. Sounds sitcomish but its defiantly and deliriously not so Kazik Radwanskis captivating feature debut framed tightly and in shallow focus pulls us face-to-face with a character who seems about to explode at any moment. PHWest of Memphis Oscar-winning filmmaker Amy Berg (Deliver Us From Evil) is a camera-toting crusader to right a lengthy wrong done to three teenage boys. Several witnesses tearfully recant testimony onscreen while DNA evidence points to a shocking new suspect in the case that saw a trio of innocent Arkansas teens -- dubbed the West Memphis 3 -- jailed for 18 years for the murders of three 8-year-old boys. The docs revelations are based on fresh evidence gathered by private investigators hired by The Lord of the Rings Peter Jackson and his wife Fran Walsh who are also co-producers on the documentary along with Damien Echols one of the charged and his wife Lori Davis. A stunning look at a miscarriage of justice that nearly ended in Echols execution. Daily Edition Login to download Dredd 3D Film Review 1040 AM PDT 9/2/2012 by Stephen Dalton FACEBOOK TWITTER EMAIL ME PRINT COMMENTS Cult comic-strip character rebooted for the 3D age TWITTER Futuristic lawman returns in superior sci-fi action thriller scripted by Alex Garland. A cult anti-hero born 35 years ago on the pages of the long-running British comic book 2000 AD Judge Dredd began life as a kind of futuristic Dirty Harry an ultraviolent fantasy of a US lawman policing a dystopian Blade Runner universe. His fascistic worldview dispensing hard-edged instant justice on the mean streets of Mega City One offered readers both a guilty pleasure and a darkly satirical commentary on Anglo-American society in the late 1970s just as punk rock was fading and the Thatcher-Reagan era was dawning. In Dredd 3D this evergreen pop-culture icon gets rebooted for the 21st century by Alex Garland author of The Beach and screenwriter of 28 Days Later among many others. A previous attempt to bring Dredd to the screen director Danny Cannons 1995 star vehicle for Sylvester Stallone impressed neither serious fans nor mainstream movie-goers. But Garland and director Pete Travis deliver a sharper and better film more faithful to the original comic but careful not to be too culturally specific and targeted squarely at the huge global market for sci-fi thrillers. While its R rating will inevitably limit commercial potential this is a superior genre piece which ticks enough effects-heavy action-franchise boxes to generate healthy box office. Where Cannons film was geographically expansive clumsily comic and heavily sanitised for family viewing Dredd 3D takes exactly the opposite approach. The violence here is graphic and gory taking full advantage of that R rating. The dark ironic very British humour of the original strip has been largely excised. And nine-tenths of the story takes place inside a single location a vast housing project which has become a lawless high-rise ghetto controlled by the ruthlessly sadistic drugs pusher and crime boss Ma-Ma (Headey). When Dredd (Urban) and his rookie partner the psychic Judge Anderson (Thirlby) arrive to investigate a triple homicide they become prisoners of this violent mega-slum fighting for survival against Ma-Mas heavily armed foot soldiers. The limited location computer game-style plot and muted humour of Dredd 3D may disappoint hardcore fans of the comic book. While the vast post-apocalyptic sprawl of Mega City One almost functioned like a main character in the original strips here we only see it in teasing glimpses as a chaotic concrete jungle stretching off to the far horizon. Most of the film was shot in South Africa which perhaps explains why this ostensibly US Eastern seaboard cityscape looks more like Johannesburg than Boston or Manhattan. Dredd purists will perhaps approve more of Karl Urbans minimalist portrayal barking terse commands from behind his ever-present mask in-keeping with his comic-strip blueprint. But it still lacks something a one-dimensional performance in a three-dimensional film. The Die Hard-level plot also contains a few risibly silly contrivances notably the photogenic Anderson being sent into an urban war zone despite forgetting to wear her protective helmet. Doh That said Dredd 3D constantly impresses on a visual level with a gritty style more akin to cult hits like District 9 or 28 Days Later than to standard Hollywood comic-book blockbusters. The esteemed British cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle best known for his Lars Von Trier collaborations and his Oscar-winning work on Danny Boyles Slumdog Millionaire adds to the projects overall air of high-level craftsmanship. His first venture into 3D is a blaze of saturated colours gorgeous high-resolution close-ups and dazzling slow-motion sequences. Imagine the balletic slowed-down carnage of vintage Sam Peckinpah or John Woo but taken to the next technological level. Pitched at the right level to please original fans but still slick and accessible enough to attract new ones Dredd 3D feels like a smart and muscular addition to the sci-fi action genre. Even 35 years later Judge Dredd still packs a hard punch. Go ahead punk. Make his day. "Guilty pleasure" is a term youll often hear associated with action films like "Dredd 3D". But I say "no more" to this whole line of thought. We must cast off our guilt as that guilt is built upon the faulty premise that an action movie cant bring anything more to the table than spectacle. Not so for this movie. This time around feel free to stow your shame firmly at the door. Get on board with Karl Urban It sounds like sacrilege but "Dredd 3D" is the rare remake/reboot thats actually far superior to the original. One could make the case that it was only a sentimental and misplaced nostalgia that even allowed for this version to exist but it doesnt excuse the fact that Sly Stallones "Judge Dredd" was a cheesy wreck. Lovable? Sure just like a puppy and with similar messiness issues. Thankfully "Dredd 3D" is a real movie with a logical plot and solid action. Featuring dynamic acting even In the future world of "Dredd 3D" only 80 million people have survived and all of them are inhabitants of Mega-City 1. They are arranged in districts and judges (like our buddy Dredd) act as policeman juries and executioners where the law is concerned. Dredd (Karl Urban) must choose the crimes he prosecutes carefully as there are 12 crimes in the city every minute and very few judges are left to mete out justice. On this particular day Dredd finds himself saddled with a trainee named Anderson (Olivia Thirlby). Its a classic "Traning Day" scenario and weve all been there. The mismatched duo heads off to sector 13 to a concrete hamlet charmingly named "Peach Trees" home to 75000 citizens and one absolutely ruthless gang called the Ma-Mas. Also Check Out Stars Take the Red Carpet at the 2012 Toronto Film Festival Ma-Ma (Lena Headey) is the diabolical leader of the Ma-Mas fittingly and shes decided she cant allow Dredd and Anderson to interrogate one of her gang captains. Have you ever met a person who just wont listen to reason? Thats Dredd vs. Ma-Ma two stone-cold hard cases with legitimate iron wills. Dredd isnt leaving until Ma-Ma faces judgement ... and Ma-Ma isnt going anywhere or being judged on any level by Judge Dredd. Immovable object meet the unstoppable force. This antagonistic relationship informs the entire plot so your enjoyment of this stubbornly violent dichotomy will go a long way toward forming your overall opinion of the movie. On the acting front Karl Urban owns the part of Judge Dredd. Hes got none of the silliness of the original "Judge Dredd" instead replacing it with a determined scowl and a gruff surliness. Lena Headey also does legitimate work as Ma-Ma channeling her best impression of Gary Oldman from "True Romance." Olivia Thirlby brings a quiet competence to trainee Anderson alternating vulnerability with a "fail fast forward" mentality that youd expect out of a recruit. Then there is the action quotient which is high to quite high. While Im not convinced that this film exactly needed to be in 3-D I was at least impressed with the overall level of visual effects. The Ma-Mas are drug traffickers peddling a narcotic named "Slo-mo" and the film does excellent work in showing off the drugs effects. The pacing is also stellar theres not a dull moment but its also not completely frenetic and aimless. As we pass judgment on "Dredd" its clear that the only guilt you should feel is if you skip it entirely. Other than that sit back and enjoy the movie earns every morsel of entertainment goodness. Grim gritty and ultra-violent "Dredd" reinstates the somber brutality missing from the U.K. comicbook icons previous screen outing the disappointing 1995 Sylvester Stallone starrer "Judge Dredd." A reboot as drastic as Christopher Nolans "Batman Begins" this hard-R sci-fi actioner from director Pete Travis and screenwriter Alex Garland should find an appreciative audience among serious-minded fanboys and gorehounds while the pics more extreme elements will likely limit its potential of crossing over to the superhero mainstream when Lionsgate releases it domestically Sept. 21. At a time when most comicbook adaptations try to be all things to all people "Dredd" makes the radical choice of playing to the base. Dredd-heads disappointed by the creative liberties and concessions to conventionality made by the Stallone version will find little reason to quibble with the determined and unapologetic approach to the one-man judge jury and executioner here. Theres no comic-relief sidekick no love interest no movie-star pandering. In a direct nod to the source this Dredd never even removes his face-obscuring helmet remaining a stoic and mysterious figure throughout. The action unfolds on a futuristic Earth ravaged by wars and divided into overcrowded urban centers known as Mega-Cities patrolled by Judges members of an all-powerful police force equipped with the latest technology and bestowed with the responsibility of rendering life-or-death verdicts at the scene of a crime. The irreproachable Judge Dredd (Karl Urban) who safeguards Mega-City One is asked to evaluate rookie Cassandra Anderson (Olivia Thirlby) an Academy underachiever who nevertheless possesses extraordinary psychic abilities She can read minds a rather invaluable trick for solving crimes. When Dredd and Cassandra respond to a triple-homicide call in a high-rise they find themselves battling ruthless drug lord Ma-Ma (Lena Headey) a former prostitute who now rules with an iron fist over the 200-story vertical slum. Ma-Ma has evaded capture while supplying Mega-City One with a potent narcotic called Slo-Mo which allows users to experience reality at a fraction of its normal speed -- but shes never faced Judge Dredd. The films unforgiving version of Dredd is something of a cross between Christian Bales Batman and Clint Eastwoods Man With No Name. Hes a badass of few words and a gravelly voice. While Urban isnt permitted to reveal much humanity behind the man (we never even get a peek at Dredds eyes beneath his uniform helmet let alone his soul) he does a fine job embodying the more mythic qualities of Dredd as an upright law enforcer no lowlife would want to confront. That leaves Thirlby to shoulder the films emotional core and the physically unassuming actress proves up to the challenge of a meaty role. Cassandra is as committed to taking down criminals as Dredd but she also harbors a deep reserve of empathy that stems from being able to see into other peoples minds. One of the films true thrills comes in watching Thirlby effortlessly balance the conflict between a Judges merciless duties and a psychics compassionate understanding. Of course "Dredd" also serves up thrills far less nuanced than its heroines inner struggles. Relentless carnage bombards the viewer from all sides even more so in impressively utilized 3D. Heads are smashed bullets rip through body parts and one larynx is memorably destroyed accompanied by the throbbing sounds of Paul Leonard-Morgans bass-heavy original score. Even though both the heroes and the villains prove equally barbarous theres never any question as to whos good or bad in this black-and-white world. Its only through Cassandras emotional arc that the audience sees any cracks in the totalitarian justice system. As suggested by the wild shift in quality between his breakout docudrama "Omagh" and underwhelming follow-up "Vantage Point" director Travis is only as strong as his source material. He gets a sturdy B-movie foundation here from Garland who sets the tone by taking comicbook characters and situations seriously. This earnest approach is evident in tech credits as well most notably Anthony Dod Mantles cinematography which eschews the jittery handheld imagery of Travis earlier films for more careful compositions. The judiciously spread-out "Slo-Mo" sequences are especially eye-catching. Editor Mark Eckersley gets a workout in a trippy sequence in which Cassandra enters the mind of a remorseless prisoner (Wood Harris) and production designer Mark Digby relishes the details of establishing a functioning city (including a medical center eateries and even a movie theater) within a massive high-rise.
